awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A New Model Order Reduction Framework for the Control of Advanced Propulsion and Energy Storage Systems for Electrified Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project will investigate a novel framework that systematically transfers the accuracy and fidelity of physics-based models into low-order models suitable for control design of automotive propulsion systems. Automotive propulsion technologies have become considerably complex as manufacturers strive to improve fuel economy, emissions, safety and the driver experience. Such complexity requires the adoption of advanced control and estimation algorithms. The project will provide the necessary tools to control engineers who need to employ high-fidelity, physics-based models, albeit with considerably reduced complexity. The research will be directly applied to the estimation of thermal imbalances in Li-ion battery packs for high-performance electric vehicles, and to the estimation and control of surge dynamics in downsized boosted engines, two key technologies for current and future automotive powertrains. The automotive industry will participate to the research by providing insights and facilitating technology transfer. Research, education and outreach will be integrated through the Buckeye Current electric motorcycle team at The Ohio State University, inspired by e-mobility, e-racing and sustainable transportation. Integration will be also pursued through the enrichment of existing courses, creation of web-based teaching tools and student internship programs, and by collaborating with the Teaching Engineering to K-8 (TEK8) programs to attract young talents from underrepresented groups.

The state of the art for model-based control design relies almost exclusively on low-fidelity models based on empirical approaches and on approximations of the physical system, which ultimately leads a loss of accuracy. This research introduces a transformative framework that analytically generates control-oriented models from the conservation laws for thermal, fluid and chemical systems in nonlinear Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) form. A projection-based Model Order Reduction (MOR) will be applied to generate Reduced Order Models (ROM) whose parameters are directly derived from physical constants through analytical relations, dramatically reducing the need for calibration. The projection will enforce specific properties "a priori" in the resulting ROM, namely stability, observability and controllability. Case studies will be conducted on the estimation of thermal imbalances in Li-ion battery packs for high-performance electric vehicles, and the estimation and control of surge dynamics in downsized boosted engines.

por.por_cntn:
This CAREER award led to the creation of a novel model order reduction (MOR) framework able to transfer the accuracy and fidelity of physics-based models (based on Partial Differential Equations, PDEs) into low-order models (based on Ordinary Differential Equations, ODEs) suitable for the design of control and estimation algorithms. By bridging this research gap, the project provided the necessary tools to control designers who seek to utilize physically accurate models of the plant, however with considerably reduced mathematical complexity and virtually no calibration requirements.

The developed framework hinges on applying a continuous Galerkin Projection to the Boundary Value Problem (BVP), comprisng nonlinear parabolic PDEs along with state-dependent parameters, complex and intra-domain boundary conditions. The novelty of the framework is the definition of a projection basis that is not numerically induced from data (such as in Proper Orthogonal Decomposition, POD), but rather defined analytically through a set of orthogonal basis functions that are dependent on the mathematical nature of the problem. Imposing the orthogonality of the inner product yields a redundant set of ODEs in the reduced order model (ROM), where the states are the time-varying coefficients of the basis functions. Then, applying the projection method to the boundary conditions of the original PDE problem results into an additional set of algebraic constraints that allows one to further reduce the number of states.

Compared to the POD-Galerkin theory, this method does not require extensive characterizations of the field (either via experiments or simulation) in order to define the basis functions, thus offering a data-free solution.  The framework was demonstrated for nonlinear parabolic (diffusion) and advection-diffusion BVPs, with a extension to hyperbolic problem with regular boundary conditions. Specific procedures were created to verify the stability and approximation error of the ROM for different orders of model truncation.

The theory and methods developed during this project were demonstrated through multiple practical applications, including physics-based (electrochemical) modeling of li-ion batteries for electric vehicles, thermal modeling of automotive three way catalysts, and wave propagation in turbocharged engine air path systems during unstable (surge) operations. The research results were disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and a robust outreach to the automotive industry, which actively participated to the research activity, facilitated technology transfer and provided directly funded applied research. Research collaborations were established with the Polytechnic of Milan and the University of Genoa (Italy), through student exchanges and joint publications. The research created in this project was integrated into short courses and a graduate course offered at two Universities.

The project actively engaged students from underrepresented minority groups, including two female graduate students and four female undergraduate students. The PI collaborated with the Teaching Engineering to K-8 (TEK-8) program supported by the OSU College of Engineering to train engineering students in creating and organizing engineering design challenges for middle-school students in underserved communities.  Community outreach was also conducted through the OSU Buckeye Current team, educating engineering students and raise societal awareness on the opportunities and benefits of electric mobility and sustainable transportation.
